facts.text: Appellants, partners of M/s. Navinchandra Co., placed order with respondent for 251 bales of printed chints on or about July 4, 1942, accepted by respondent letters dated July 11 and July 20, 1942, delivery fixed for September and October 1942.
Appellants placed another order with respondent for 31 bales of printed chints on July 24, 1942, accepted on July 25, 1942, delivery in October 1942.
Workers in respondent mills went on strike on August 9, 1942, in sympathy with Quit India movement.
Respondent wrote to appellants on August 15, 1942 (Ex. P.78), stating delivery time of all pending contracts automatically extended for period working stopped and till normal state of affairs recurs.
Strike ended, mills resumed working on November 22, 1942.
On December 5, 1942, appellants Keshavlal and Ratilal approached Jasubhai (then in charge of mills management) for delivery, told contracts void, no delivery.
Jasubhai wrote to appellants on December 6, 1942 (Ex. P.62), contracts null and void, not binding.
Managing agency of mills: Chinubhai Lalbhai in charge when contracts made; on September 18, 1942, fell to Jasubhai and Babubhai after compromise.
Appellants wrote to respondent on December 17, 1942, stating respondent bound to deliver due to extension letter of August 15, 1942, threatened legal proceedings.
Respondent replied on December 20, 1942, repeating contentions.
Appellants formally demanded delivery in January and February 1943, not complied with.
Appellants filed suit on January 9, 1946, claiming Rs. 1,52,334-8-9 damages for breach, with interest and costs; alleged suit in time due to acceptance of extension request.
Trial court (Civil Judge Senior Division, Ahmedabad, Suit No. 10 of 1946, judgment July 30, 1949) decreed appellants' claim, found in favour on extension and limitation.

Bombay High Court (Appeal No. 642 of 1949, judgment April 17, 1950) allowed respondent's appeal, dismissed suit: rejected oral evidence of acceptance, conduct not showing acceptance, letter vague/uncertain, suit barred by limitation.
Ratilal (PW1) testified: 4-5 days after Aug 15 letter, met Chinubhai at mills office, orally accepted extension; no other matters discussed, no written confirmation.
Keshavlal corroborated Ratilal; after mills reopened, both demanded delivery from Jasubhai per contracts.

Chinubhai testified: Proposal conveyed by Laxmidas under instructions; similar requests to all constituents; did not remember written reply but effect suggests oral acceptance; later said did not remember if accepted.
No demands for delivery made by appellants on original due dates.
Sauda books brought to trial court by Shri Dharamasi Harilal but not exhibited by either party.
Prices of goods rising at material time.
Respondent's pleas on contract invalidity and Laxmidas' letter unauthorised negatived in courts below; attitude actuated by Jasubhai's prejudice against Chinubhai.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was agreement between parties for extension of time for performance of contracts, proved by oral evidence or conduct.
Whether the agreement to extend time in respondent's letter dated August 15, 1942, was vague and uncertain, rendering it void under s.29 Indian Contract Act.
Whether suit barred by limitation absent valid extension.

petitioner_arguments.text: Oral evidence of Ratilal and Keshavlal reliable: Ratilal orally accepted extension to Chinubhai 4-5 days after Aug 15 letter; corroborated by Keshavlal and Chinubhai; no reason to disbelieve.
Conduct consistent with acceptance: No demand on original due dates; first demand after mills reopened on Dec 5; rising prices made extension beneficial.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.63 Indian Contract Act; extension may be proved by oral evidence or conduct; forbearance to demand relevant.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sauda books not exhibited by respondent infers they showed endorsement of extension.
Second condition in letter ('till normal state of affairs recurs') meaningless surplusage, ignore it; extension only for stoppage period.
Plea of vagueness not raised in trial court or appeal grounds; should not be entertained.

respondent_arguments.text: No agreement on extension; oral evidence unreliable; conduct does not show acceptance.
Letter Aug 15, 1942 vague/uncertain, esp. 'till normal state of affairs recurs'; cannot ascertain definite period.
Contracts void and not binding; letter unauthorised.
Sauda books not exhibited by appellants infers no endorsement of extension.

court_reasoning.text: Oral evidence of Ratilal and Keshavlal true and reliable; corroborated by conduct (no early demand, first after reopening); Chinubhai not inconsistent; respondent's untenable pleas show lack of bona fides.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence and probabilities support acceptance of proposal to extend time.

court_reasoning.text: Letter's second condition ('till normal state of affairs recurs') vague/uncertain: ambiguous whether political or mills working; even if mills, constituent elements (workmen, raw material, coal etc.) not specified; no consensus ad idem.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreement void for uncertainty under s.29 Contract Act despite acceptance.

court_reasoning.text: Nicolene distinguished: Second condition essential part of proposal, not meaningless surplusage; both conditions must be agreed for valid extension under s.63.
Scammell applied: Words fail to evince definite meaning; diverse explanations confirm vagueness.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No enforceable contract where terms uncertain.

court_reasoning.text: Plea of vagueness allowable in appeal: pure question of law on document construction; no extrinsic evidence under s.93 Evidence Act.
Sauda books: Unsafe to draw adverse inferences either way.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decision on oral evidence and conduct.

holdings.text: Oral acceptance of extension proposal proved.
Agreement to extend time void for vagueness and uncertainty under s.29 Indian Contract Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Vague meaningless clause severable there; not here as essential condition of extension proposal.
Vague terms prevent enforceable contract; confirmed by diverse explanations.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s.63: Promisee may extend time by agreement (oral/conduct); s.29: Agreements void for uncertainty.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: No extrinsic evidence to remove vagueness from document.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellate court may allow plea of law based on document construction.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appellants' appeal, confirmed High Court decree dismissing suit for damages due to vague extension agreement rendering suit time-barred, despite accepting proof of oral acceptance.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: "the delivery time of all your pending contracts with us shall be automatically understood as extended for the period the working is stopped and till the normal state of affairs recurs."
key_quotes.speaker: respondent
key_quotes.significance: Core of the vague extension proposal central to decision.

key_quotes.text: "If these words, considered however broadly and untechnically and with due regard to all the just implications, fail to evince any definite meaning on which the court can safely act, the court has no choice but to say that there is no contract."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Scammell, applied to hold extension void.

key_quotes.text: "we confirm the finding of the High Court on the question of vagueness or uncertainty of the agreement to extend time and that must inevitably lead to the dismissal of the present appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We are, however, free to state that we have reached this conclusion with some reluctance because we are satisfied that there are no bona fides in the attitude adopted by the respondent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
